step.context: \text{\textbf{Check Point } \#1:which of the following is}\\ \text{mathematically correct?}

\int_{1}^{2}\left(\dfrac{1}{x} - \dfrac{1}{2x^2}\right) e^2x dx = \lambda\int_{m}^{n}e^t \left[f \left(t\right) + f^{\prime} \left(x\right)\right]dt\\ \text{What should }t=? \text{ And therefore, are }\lambda,m,n,\\ f \left(t\right) \text{ and }f^{\prime}\left(t\right)?
step.reason: \text{If }t = 2x, \text{then }dx = \dfrac{dt}{2}\\ \text{Also }\underbrace{t =2}_{m} \text{ when }x =1 \text{ and }\underbrace{t =4 }_{n}\text{ when } x =2\\ \begin{align} \therefore &\int_{1}^{2}e^{2x}\left(\dfrac{1}{x}-\dfrac{1}{2x}\right).dx\\ &= \dfrac{1}{2}\int_{2}^{4}e^t \left[\dfrac{1}{\dfrac{t}{2}}-\dfrac{1}{2 \left(\dfrac{t}{2}\right)^2}\right] dt\\ &= \dfrac{1}{2}\int_{2}^{4}e^t \left[\dfrac{2}{t}-\dfrac{2}{t^2}\right] dt=\int_{2}^{4} e^t\left[\dfrac{1}{t} - \dfrac{1}{t^2}\right]dt \\ \end{align}\\ \text{Notice that }-\dfrac{1}{t^2} = \dfrac{d}{dt}\left(\dfrac{1}{t}\right)\\ \therefore A = \int_{2}^{4}e^t \left(\dfrac{1}{t} - \dfrac{1}{t^2}\right).dt=\int_{2}^{4}e^t \left[f \left(t\right) + f^{\prime} \left(t\right)\right]dt\\ \text{Where }f \left(t\right) = \dfrac{1}{t}\text{ and }f^{\prime}\left(t\right)=-\dfrac{1}{t^2}
